We decouple caging and hopping dynamics, so that $\xi_\text{\tiny G}$ and ${\xi_\text{\tiny NG}}$ are uncorrelated processes. For symmetry reasons, only the $2n$-time correlation functions of ${\xi_\text{\tiny NG}}$ are non zero. We will give arguments on the robustness of our results with respect to the noise statistics, as long as the absence of persistence time is conserved. We will explicitly demonstrate that the scale invariance of the small displacement distribution is indeed insensitive to the specifics of the hop distribution, but the exponential crossover regime to a Gaussian rests on a typical exponential distribution of cage hops.


We distinguish the passive and active fluctuations of the particle. The former are associated with the confined motion of the particle in a steady cage, as measured by $D$. The latter are induced by the cage hops, thus describing the motion in a non-confined environment characterized by the diffusion coefficient ${D_\text{\tiny A}}={\varepsilon}^2/\tau_0$. The coexistence of both Gaussian and non-Gaussian noises is crucially important to enhance non-Gaussian nature~\cite{Kanazawa:15}.





\textit{Mean-square displacement and non-Gaussianity}.---As a first insight into the dynamics of our model, we study the time evolution of the mean-square displacement (MSD), controlled by three independent parameters $\{{D},{D_\text{\tiny A}},{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}\}$. It is diffusive at short and long times with diffusion coefficients ${D}$ and ${D_\text{\tiny A}}$, respectively [Fig.~\ref{fig:sum}(a)]. The predictions for a steady and a hopping cage coincide at times shorter than ${t^*}={\tau_\text{\tiny R}}{D}/{D_\text{\tiny A}}=\tau_0({\sigma}/{\varepsilon})^2$, referred to as the passive regime. This shows that the effect of the active fluctuations is hidden as long as the typical distance covered by the cage ${\varepsilon}\sqrt{t/\tau_0}$ is smaller than the cage size ${\sigma}$. Between the two diffusions, a plateau regime appears when ${D_\text{\tiny A}}\ll{D}$, as an evidence of the cage effect, and we observe a transient superdiffusion if ${D_\text{\tiny A}}\gg{D}$. The time when the MSD deviates from the plateau, equal to ${t^*}$, can be shifted to an arbitrary large value. Conversely, the time when superdiffusion arises, also equal to ${t^*}$, can be arbitrarily short~\cite{supp,Rao:14}. Our model contains the existence of ballistic directed events, as assessed by the superdiffusion, even if there is no persistence time in its formulation. 


The deviation of the displacement distribution from Gaussian is quantified by the non-Gaussian parameter (NGP), defined as $\avg{\Delta x^4}/3/\avg{\Delta x^2}^2 -1$. It characterizes the amount of directed events in the particle trajectory, thus probing the structural rearrangements of the system. Its evolution is determined by $\{{D_\text{\tiny A}}/{D},{\tau_\text{\tiny R}},\tau_0\}$, where $\tau_0$ only affects the amplitude. The NGP vanishes at short and long time, corresponding to the passive and active Gaussian regimes, respectively. It takes positive values in the transient regime, for which the distribution is broader than Gaussian [Fig.~\ref{fig:sum}(b)]. When ${D_\text{\tiny A}}\ll{D}$, the peak time equals $t^*$, namely the time when the MSD deviates from the transient plateau, as assessed in colloidal systems~\cite{Weeks:00,Weeks:02,Weeks:07,Weeks:15,Kilfoil:09}, and the peak value reads $({\varepsilon}/{\sigma})^2/2$. When ${D_\text{\tiny A}}\gg{D}$, there is a plateau regime around the peak value, equal to $2\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}$. In both cases, the NGP starts to decrease when the long time diffusive regime sets in.

\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:tP}
\tilde P(q,t) &=& \exp \cur{ -\f{ {\tau_\text{\tiny R}} q{\varepsilon} /\tau_0 }{1+(q{\varepsilon})^2} \brt{ \f{q{\varepsilon} t}{{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}}  -\arctan\pnt{q{\varepsilon}{f_t}} } }

\\

\end{eqnarray}
where ${f_t}=1-{\text{e}}^{-t/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}}$~\cite{supp}. The displacement distribution is Gaussian at short and long times, corresponding respectively to the passive and active diffusions. In the intermediate transient regime, it is Gaussian for small and large displacements, with a non-Gaussian cross-over in between.


The accessible range of displacements for experimental and simulated systems does not always allow one to observe the large Gaussian part of the distribution (they can clearly be seen, though, in \cite{Kilfoil:09}). The existence of directed events is quantified through the deviation from the central Gaussian, that is \textit{via} the cross-over between the two Gaussian parts. Within our model, it is given by exponential tails, as commonly reported in glassy systems~\cite{Berthier:07}, of the form ${\text{e}}^{ - \abs{\Delta x} / \pnt{ {\varepsilon} {f_t} } }$. 


To demonstrate that our model is sufficient to capture the transition from a central Gaussian part to exponential tails in glassy systems, we compare our results with existing data for a dense suspension of colloidal particles~\cite{Kilfoil:09} and a binary Lennard-Jones mixture~\cite{Berthier:07, Berthier:07b}. For the colloidal system, we reproduce the time evolution of the distribution with parameters $\cur{\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}, {\varepsilon}/\sigma} = \cur{25, 6}$ [Fig.~\ref{fig:sum}(c)]. In the Lennard-Jones mixture, the measurements are taken for four temperatures at the $\alpha$ relaxation time, corresponding to $t^*$ within our model (see below). The central Gaussian part barely varies whereas the tails decrease with temperature. It depends on the hopping statistics only \textit{via} the typical waiting time $\tau_0$ between two successive cage hops, thus being independent of the hopping length ${\varepsilon}$. Besides, this result remains unchanged for any hopping distribution. This suggests that the  intermediate displacement distribution is an appropriate probe to reveal universal behavior in glassy systems.


Equation~\eqref{eq:1F1} reveals that the intermediate displacement distribution is scale invariant. The existence of a master curve for the scaled Van Hove function has already been reported in colloidal systems~\cite{Weeks:00,Weeks:02}. Within our model, a convenient scaling factor is given by ${\sigma}\sqrt{2{f_t}/(1-{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}/\tau_0)}$, namely the standard deviation of the central Gaussian part. The asymptotic solution for intermediate scaled displacements is entirely determined by $\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}$, its central part being invariant under modification of this parameter. The deviation from Gaussianity is characterized by power-law tails with the exponent ${\tau_\text{\tiny R}}/\tau_0-1$. As $\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}$ increases, the transition from Gaussian to power-law behavior becomes sharper, and the power-law exponent tends to $-1$.


An important quantity of interest is the typical scaled displacement of the cross-over between the central Gaussian part and the tails. We predict that the cross-over value $X$ depends weakly on $\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}$ for large values of this parameter, $X$ varying approximately between three and five when $\tau_0/{\tau_\text{\tiny R}}$ spans three decades from $10^2$ to $10^5$ (see Fig.~(S2) in~\cite{supp}). A cross-over value of order one is consistent with experimental observations~\cite{Weeks:00,Weeks:02}.
